  1689. Given the following dialogue, answer to the question. “Dialogue”: [“A: Hello, School of English Studies.”, “B: Hello, I saw your advertisement in the newspaper. Can you give me some information, please?”, “A: Yes, of course. What would you like to know?”, “B: Well, first, how long are the courses?”, “A: They are 6 or 9 months long and the next course begins next Monday.”, “B: How many students will there be in the class? Not too many, I hope.”, “A: Usually, there are 15. We find that a good number.”, “B: OK. Now, I saw the price of the course in the newspaper, but will I have to pay for anything else?”, “A: Only for the textbook, which costs twelve pounds ninety-nine.”, “B: I see. When can I come and pay?”, “A: Well, the school is open from 8 am to 7 pm Monday to Friday and on Saturdays from 9 am to 1 pm.”, “B: OK. I see. Well, thank you very much. Goodbye.”], “Target”: “OK. I see. Well, thank you very much. Goodbye.”, “Question”: “What is or could be the motivation of target?”

    The speaker is happy to get the required detail of the course from the listener.

  1690. Given the following dialogue, answer to the question. “Dialogue”: [“A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?”, “B: There are several places.   1691. My husband was very violent especially when intoxicated with alcohol and could harrass and abuse our 3 kids as well. They have been take by the social services . Will i be involved when finding social service for them?

    I’m not a legal professional, but I can try to offer some general information that might help. In most cases, the involvement of a parent whose children have been taken by social services depends on the circumstances and the decisions made by the authorities. If you want to be involved in the process of finding social services (such as foster care or support programs) for your children, it may be a good idea to cooperate with social service agencies, demonstrate your commitment to creating a safe environment for your children, and attend any associated court hearings or meetings.

    However, every situation is different, so it’s crucial to seek legal advice from a professional familiar with the laws and regulations in your area. A lawyer or legal aid organization may be able to provide more specific guidance on your rights and options in this situation.

  1692. I recently moved from England to Scotland. I am pregnant and have two kids aged 3 and 12 and have not registered for voting in Scotland. Am I eligible for Healthy Start scheme ?

    Yes, you may be eligible for the Healthy Start scheme in Scotland if you meet the following criteria:

    1. You are at least 10 weeks pregnant or have a child under four years old.

    2. You or your family get one of the following benefits:

      • Income Support

      • Income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance

      • Income-related Employment and Support Allowance

      • Child Tax Credit (with a family income of £16,190 or less per year)

      • Universal Credit (with a family take home pay of £408 or less per month)

      • Pension Credit

    As a pregnant woman or a family with children under the age of four, you would be entitled to receive free vitamin supplements, vouchers to spend on milk, plain fresh or frozen fruit and vegetables, and infant formula milk under the Healthy Start scheme.

    It is essential to first register for the benefits you or your family are eligible for. Then, apply for the Healthy Start scheme by downloading the application form from the official website (https://www.healthystart.nhs.uk/healthy-start-vouchers/how-to-apply/), filling it in, and having it signed by a healthcare professional (e.g., a midwife or a health visitor).

    Remember that you need to register to vote in Scotland to ensure you are accurately assessed for the benefits you can receive. This can be done online at the following link: https://www.gov.uk/register-to-vote

    For more information and guidance, you can visit Citizen’s Advice Scotland (https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/scotland/) and engage with a local support network.

  1693. I have two daughters, the elder of which is 14. After she became involved in petty crime and substance abuse my local council sought and obtained an Interim Care Order regarding her, and are now seeking a Placement Order by which she can be fostered. She has so far been with them for six weeks. How long can the council detain my child before a hearing is held before a court?

    I’m not a legal expert, but I can try to provide some general information that may be helpful.

    In most jurisdictions, the time frame for a hearing to take place after a child has been taken into care varies. It’s important to consult with a legal expert in your area to better understand the specific laws applicable to your situation. Generally, after an Interim Care Order is granted, a hearing should be scheduled within a few weeks.

    In the meantime, it may be valuable for you to consult with a solicitor or legal aid service who specializes in family law to gain a better understanding of your rights, the timeline for court proceedings, and the steps that can be taken to best advocate for your daughter’s welfare and reunification with your family. They can provide you with specific advice tailored to your circumstances and guide you through the process.

  1694. My grandfather is terminally ill and the doctor said he has 2 months left. I want to apply for a parental leave to take my children with me to go and visit him during his last days. Am i eligible for a paid or unpaid parental leave?

    I’m not an expert in labor laws, but I can try to provide some general information that might help. Eligibility for parental leave can vary depending on your location, your employer’s policies, and the specific type of leave you’re seeking. In some places, family or medical leave, rather than parental leave, might be more applicable for your situation. This could potentially be paid or unpaid, depending on your jurisdiction and your employer’s policies.

    If you’re located in the U.S., you may qualify for the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA) which can provide up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for eligible employees to care for a family member with a serious health condition. Keep in mind that eligibility for FMLA depends on factors such as the size of the company you work for and how long you’ve been employed by them.

    I’d recommend reaching out to your employer’s HR department for specific information on their policies and to explore your options for taking time off to be with your grandfather. I hope this helps, and I’m sorry to hear about your grandfather’s situation.

  1695. I am 24 and have been dating my fiance for several years. We are now engaged and want to get married at a register office. How much does it cost to book a registrar at a register office?

    The cost of booking a registrar at a register office can vary depending on the location and the specific services you require. In general, the fees can range from £46 to over £400, depending on the type of ceremony and the day of the week you choose to get married. It’s best to check with your local register office for the most accurate and up-to-date pricing information.

  1696. I live in London and have recently had a baby boy and am very interested in getting onto the Healthy Start scheme but I do not know much about it. Can someone tell me if I am eligible for the Healthy Start scheme?

    Healthy Start scheme provides help to eligible pregnant women and families with young children to buy basic foods like milk, fruit, and vegetables. In order to be eligible for the Healthy Start scheme in the UK, you must meet the following criteria:

    1. Be at least 10 weeks pregnant or have a child under four years old.

    2. Be in receipt of certain benefits such as:

      1. Income Support

      2. Income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance

      3. Income-related Employment and Support Allowance

      4. Child Tax Credit (with a family income of £16,190 or less per year)

      5. Working Tax Credit run-on (paid for 4 weeks after you

        stop qualifying for Working Tax Credit)

      6. Universal Credit with a family income of £408 or less per month.

    In addition, if you are under 18 and pregnant, you qualify for the Healthy Start vouchers even if you are not receiving any of the above benefits or tax credits.

    To apply for the Healthy Start scheme, visit the official Healthy Start website (https://www.healthystart.nhs.uk/) and download the application form or ask your midwife, health visitor, or GP for a copy. It requires to be filled out, signed by a healthcare professional, and then mailed to the mentioned address on the form. If you are deemed eligible, you will receive vouchers for milk, fruit, and vegetables, as well as coupons for vitamins tailored for pregnant women, new moms, and young children.

  1697. I am a British citizen currently residing in England, and wish to marry my partner who is a citizen of France. After marrying we intend to live together here in the UK for the forseeable future. Does my partner require a visa, and if so which type?

    As a British citizen marrying an EU citizen, your partner may need to apply for a visa to reside with you in the UK after the end of the Brexit transition period.

    If your partner arrives in the UK before December 31, 2020, they can apply for the EU Settlement Scheme. They will be granted either “settled status” or “pre-settled status”, which will allow them to live in the UK.

    If your partner arrives in the UK from January 1, 2021, onwards, they will need to apply for a family visa as the spouse of a British citizen. They will need to meet certain financial, language, and relationship requirements to obtain this visa. Your partner must apply from outside the UK, and the visa is usually granted for 33 months. They can extend it later for another 30 months, then apply for Indefinite Leave to Remain once they have completed 5 years in the UK.

    It is best to consult the UK government’s website for the most up-to-date information on visas and marriage regulations. You may also want to seek legal advice to ensure that you follow the correct procedures for your specific situation.

  1698. I am six months pregnant and living in Cardiff. I am receiving Universal Credit and would like to apply for the Healthy Start scheme to help me buy basic foods. How much are the Healthy Start vouchers worth?

    Healthy Start vouchers are designed to help pregnant women and families with young children buy basic foods like milk, fruit, and vegetables. As of April 2021, each Healthy Start voucher is worth £4.25 per week. You can be eligible for these vouchers if you are at least 10 weeks pregnant or have a child under four years old and receive certain benefits, such as Universal Credit. It’s important to check the eligibility criteria and apply for the scheme, which you can do by visiting the Healthy Start website at www.healthystart.nhs.uk. Remember that the value of the vouchers may change, so keep an eye on the official website for updates.

  1699. I suffer from mental health problems and do not feel able to deal with my child at the moment. I am going to ask the council about alternative care. What sort of care is available to my child as I am unable to cope right now?

    I’m not an expert, but I can try to provide you with some information you could consider. It might be best to consult with a mental health professional or a social worker for more accurate advice tailored to your situation. However, here are a few options that might be available through the council or other organizations:

    1. Temporary foster care: This is when your child is placed with a trained and caring foster family for a short period while you focus on improving your mental health.

    2. Respite care: This involves a trained caregiver providing temporary support and relief by looking after your child for a short period, either in your own home or at a specialized center.

    3. Kinship care: Your child could stay with a relative or family friend for the time being, until you’re ready to resume your caregiving responsibilities. The council may also be able to offer support for the person taking care of your child.

    4. Support services: The council or local organizations might provide parenting support, mental health services, and childcare programs designed to assist parents in need.

    Remember to reach out to your local council and a mental health professional for guidance on which option would be most suitable for you and your child’s needs.

  1700. I set up a Junior ISA for my child five years ago. They are now 14 years old and moving to France with their mother. Can I still add cash to their ISA even after they move abroad?

    Yes, you can still contribute to your child’s Junior ISA even if they move abroad. However, there are some considerations to keep in mind:

    1. If your child is classified as a non-UK resident after moving to France, they may not be eligible to open a new UK-based Junior ISA. It’s important to check the residency requirements for the specific ISA provider.

    2. Assuming the existing Junior ISA was opened before your child moved abroad, you can continue to contribute towards it until they turn 18, regardless of their residency status.

    3. If you or another contributing adult is a UK resident, you can still contribute up to the annual limit for Junior ISAs, which is £9,000 for the 2021/22 tax year.

    4. Once your child turns 18, the Junior ISA will automatically become an adult ISA, and your child will have full control over it. They may still be able to contribute to some types of UK-based adult ISAs if they are still a non-UK resident.

    It’s always a good idea to check the terms and conditions with the ISA provider, as they may have specific rules regarding residency and contributions.
